In logic, the form of the original statement is "p → ¬q" (if p, then not q), where p is "Sue chose pizza" and q is "Bob chose pasta." The statement we are trying to infer is "If Bob chose pasta, then Sue did not choose pizza," which can be logically represented as "q → ¬p" (if q, then not p).

The process of inferring "q → ¬p" from "p → ¬q" is logically valid because it is essentially the contrapositive form of the original statement. The contrapositive of a statement "p → q" is "¬q → ¬p," and it is logically equivalent to the original statement. Therefore, given "p → ¬q," we can logically infer "q → ¬p" because if the presence of p implies the absence of q, then the presence of q must imply the absence of p.
